review.title: Scientific Article Summarization Using Citation-Context and Article's Discourse Structure
review.abstract: We propose a summarization approach for scientific articles which takes advantage of citation-context and the document discourse model. While citations have been previously used in generating scientific summaries, they lack the related context from the referenced article and therefore do not accurately reflect the article's content. Our method overcomes the problem of inconsistency between the citation summary and the article's content by providing context for each citation. We also leverage the inherent scientific article's discourse for producing better summaries. We show that our proposed method effectively improves over existing summarization approaches (greater than 30% improvement over the best performing baseline) in terms of \textsc{Rouge} scores on TAC2014 scientific summarization dataset. While the dataset we use for evaluation is in the biomedical domain, most of our approaches are general and therefore adaptable to other domains.

sections.heading: 3 The summarization approach
sections.text: Our algorithm for generating scientific summaries consists of four steps: (1) extraction of the citation context, (2) grouping of citation context, (3) ranking of sentences within each group, and (4) selection of sentences for the final summary. We assume that the citation text (the text within the quoting article that refers to another article) is already known in each quoting article. We describe each step in the following subsections. Our proposed procedure generates a summary of an article with the premise that the article contains a number of citations. We refer to the article to as a "reference article." We point out that we have summarized the text of the article into sentences by using the dot algorithm to detect unattended sentence boundaries (Kiss and Strunk, 2006).

sections.heading: 3.1 Extracting the citation-context
sections.text: As described in Section 2, one problem with existing quotation-based summaries is that they lack the context of the reference paper. Therefore, our goal is to use citationcontext in the reference article to accurately reflect the reference paper. To find citation contexts, we consider each quote as an n-gram vector and use vector space model to localize the relevant text spans in the reference article. Specifically, we give the ranking of text spans r1, r2,... that have the highest similarity to c. We call the retrieved text spans reference spans. These reference spans essentially form the context for each citation. The similarity function is the cosinal similarity between the rotated normalized vectors. We have evaluated four different approaches to the formation of the citation vector.

sections.heading: 3.3 Ranking model
sections.text: To identify the most representative sentences of each group, we need a measure of the meaning of sentences. We look at the sentences in a group as graphs and classify nodes according to their meaning. An important node is a node that has many connections to other nodes. There are various ways to measure the centrality of nodes, such as the degree of nodes, the difference, the proximity and eigenvectors. Here, we opt for eigenvectors and find the most central sentences in each group using the "Power Method" (Erkan and Radev, 2004), which updates the eigenvector iteratively to convergence.

sections.heading: 3.4 Selecting the sentences for final summary
sections.text: After evaluating and classifying the sentences in each group identified either by a discourse model or by a community recognition algorithm, we use two strategies to generate the summary sentence within the summary length threshold. • Iterative: We iteratively select the uppermost sentences from each group until we reach the summary length threshold. That is, we first select the uppermost sentence from all groups, and if the threshold is not reached, we select the second sentence, etc. • Innovative: In the discourse-based method, the following order is used for selecting sentences from groups: "Hypothesis," "Method," "Results," "Implication," and "Discussion." sections.heading: 5.3 Analysis of strategies for citation-context extraction
sections.text: Figure 3 shows ROUGE-L results for 250 word summaries based on the use of different methods for citation context extraction, as described in Section 3.1. Using the citation text to extract the context is almost as effective as other methods. Keyword approaches that use the terms with high idf values to localize the context achieve slightly higher rouge L precision with minimal memory. This is expected because keyword approaches only select informative terms to extract citation contexts, resulting in commands that may not themselves be keywords but help to create meaning. Noun phrases have the highest average F score, suggesting the fact that noun phrases are good indicators of important concepts in scientific text.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: We proposed a pipeline approach to the summary of scientific articles that takes advantage of the discourse model inherent in the article and the citation contexts derived from Reference Article1. Our approach focuses on the problem of the lack of context in existing quote-based summaries. We effectively achieved improvements over several well-known summaries of the TAC2014 data set for biomedical summaries. That is, we improved in all cases via baselines; in some cases, we achieved an improvement of more than 30% in mean ROUGE values over the most powerful baseline. While the dataset we use to evaluate scientific articles is in the biomedical area, most of our approaches are general and therefore adaptable to other scientific areas.
